items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>A thermal decomposition of a cobalt-lanthanum catalyst precursor containing a mixture of cobalt and lanthanum compounds obtained by co-precipitation were studied using thermal analysis coupled with mass spectrometry (TG-MS). Studies revealed that the calcination in air at 500°C is sufficient to transform the obtained cobalt precipitate into Co<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>, but it leads to only partial decomposition of lanthanum precipitate. In order to obtain Co/La catalyst precursor containing La<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> the calcination in air at the temperature about 800°C is required. However, it is unfavorable from the point of view of textural properties of the catalyst precursor. A strong effect of storage conditions on the phase composition of the studied cobalt-lanthanum catalyst precursor, caused by the formation of lanthanum hydroxide and lanthanum carbonates from La<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> when contacting with air, was observed.</jats:p>
title: Cobalt-lanthanum catalyst precursors for ammonia synthesis: determination of calcination temperature and storage conditions

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
				<jats:p> In modern research on catalysts for NH3 synthesis a lot of attention is paid to cobalt. In this work the new catalytic systems based on cobalt are presented. Unsupported cobalt catalysts singly promoted (La or Ba) and doubly promoted (La and Ba) were prepared and tested in NH<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> synthesis reaction under commercial synthesis conditions. Characterization studies revealed that lanthanum plays a role of a structural promoter, which improves the surface of catalyst precursors and prevents from sintering during calcination. However, lanthanum has a negative effect on the reduction of cobalt oxide, but the addition of barium promoter (Co/La/Ba catalyst) diminishes the negative impact of La. The co-promotion of cobalt with lanthanum and barium results in the increasing of the active phase surface and improvement of its activity in NH<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> synthesis.</jats:p>
title: Properties and activity of the cobalt catalysts for NH3 synthesis obtained by co-precipitation – the effect of lanthanum addition

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Musical Intelligence and Foreign Language Learning</jats:title>
        <jats:p>The article discusses the potential advantage that musically gifted FL learners have in developing the speaking skill, especially in acquiring some prosodic features. Empirical findings are provided to support the assumption.</jats:p>

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
				<jats:p> A group of supported ruthenium catalysts was prepared and tested in methanation of small CO amounts (7000 ppm) in hydrogen-rich streams. High surface area graphitized carbon (484 m<jats:sup>2</jats:sup>/g) was used as a support for ruthenium and RuCl<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> was used as a Ru precursor. Some of the Ru/C systems were additionally doped with barium (Ba(NO<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> was barium precursor). The catalysts were characterized by the chemisorption technique using CO as an adsorbate. To determine the resistance of the catalysts to undesired carbon support methanation, the TG-MS experiments were performed. They revealed that the barium addition inhibits support losses. The studies of CO methanation (fl ow reactor, atmospheric pressure) have shown that some of the supported ruthenium catalysts exhibit high activities referred to the metal mass. The catalytic properties of ruthenium proved to be dependent on metal dispersion. Some of the Ru/C and Ba-Ru/C systems exhibit higher activity in CO hydrogenation than the commercial nickel-based catalyst.</jats:p>
title: Effect of the ruthenium loading and barium addition on the activity of ruthenium/carbon catalysts in carbon monoxide methanation
